pullrequest.title: Projections of the S-Z effect using SZpack

content.raw: Have you verified this works identically in serial and parallel?  In general it would be nice to avoid direct calls to MPI functions, but here it is okay since I think we need this explicitly as is.  Additionally, seeing the operations you have to do here (which sometimes work around the parallelism structure) will help guide future improvements to it.
content.html: Have you verified this works identically in serial and parallel? In general it would be nice to avoid direct calls to MPI functions, but here it is okay since I think we need this explicitly as is. Additionally, seeing the operations you have to do here (which sometimes work around the parallelism structure) will help guide future improvements to it.

pullrequest.title: Projections of the S-Z effect using SZpack

content.raw:
Hi John,

Including source would be great.  I can handle that when it goes in, but if you could add a test for the source argument that would be excellent as well.  What do you think about considering adding a test for the answer testing, too?

I've left a handful of non-pressing comments below; I like this a lot and think it brings a lot of value.  It's also quite well-written!  I think the notebook you have included absolutely should go in the docs; right now we don't have a good way of including .ipynb files automatically, but when we get that set up let's add it.

Great work.
content.html:

I've left a handful of non-pressing comments below; I like this a lot and think it brings a lot of value. It's also quite well-written! I think the notebook you have included absolutely should go in the docs; right now we don't have a good way of including .ipynb files automatically, but when we get that set up let's add it.

pullrequest.title: Projections of the S-Z effect using SZpack

content.raw: I'll add a test for the MPI stuff as well as a simple test case against an analytic result. I'm guessing that as long as I stick to low T_e and \beta and stay away from the S-Z crossover frequency I can get pretty good agreement with a test cluster with \rho(r), T(r) using just the y parameters.
content.html: I'll add a test for the MPI stuff as well as a simple test case against an analytic result. I'm guessing that as long as I stick to low T_e and \beta and stay away from the S-Z crossover frequency I can get pretty good agreement with a test cluster with \rho(r), T(r) using just the y parameters.

pullrequest.title: Projections of the S-Z effect using SZpack

content.raw:
If you take a look at the answer tests, they use a decorator named `requires_pf` to ensure that a data file is is available in the testing directory.  If the data file isn't found, the test simply never runs.

You could do something similar with SZPack.  Let us know if you have trouble getting that working.
content.html:
If you take a look at the answer tests, they use a decorator named requires_pf to ensure that a data file is is available in the testing directory. If the data file isn't found, the test simply never runs.

You could do something similar with SZPack. Let us know if you have trouble getting that working.

pullrequest.title: Projections of the S-Z effect using SZpack

content.raw:
I can reproduce this in my local copy.  This isn't actually because of a namespace collision, but because the default return value for get_field_parameter *inside field detection only* is 0.0.  See line 276 of field_info_container.py.

I think John's initial thought that we should skip the field access tests for just this field is probably the way to go.
content.html:
I can reproduce this in my local copy. This isn't actually because of a namespace collision, but because the default return value for get_field_parameter inside field detection only is 0.0. See line 276 of field_info_container.py.

I think John's initial thought that we should skip the field access tests for just this field is probably the way to go.

pullrequest.title: Projections of the S-Z effect using SZpack

description:
SZpack (http://www.chluba.de/SZpack/) is a software package written by Jens Chluba to compute the S-Z signal (thermal and kinetic, with relativistic corrections). The basic operation in this analysis module is to compute moments of the gas temperature and peculiar velocity projected along the line of sight, when can then be fed into the SZpack routines to determine the S-Z spectral distortion at a set of frequencies. It produces maps of the change in intensity at these different frequencies which can be written to PNG or FITS files. Projections can be on-axis or off-axis. It also runs in parallel.

Example notebook: 

View: https://hub.yt-project.org/nb/j0al0v

Raw: https://hub.yt-project.org/go/j0al0v

I could log the images to show more detail, but I'd have to think about the best way to present that because for low frequencies the S-Z signal is a decrement. Small detail, however. 

The only other change I would make at the moment is when this gets into 3.0 I would like to include *source* as an argument for the off-axis projection as well. 

I've also made some modifications to FITS file writing to make it more versatile as well as more consolidated. There is only one function that writes FITS files, called `write_fits` in `yt.visualization.image_writer`, and other methods that need to write FITS files (such as `FixedResolutionBuffer.export_fits`) simply call this with the correct parameters. 

I've also slightly modified `yt.visualization.image_writer.write_projection` to allow for definition of extents and axis labels, which are both off by default, so the default functionality should be the same as before. 

UPDATE: 

1) Fixed some bugs related to density weighting and the high-order contributions to the kinetic S-Z effect.  

2) Added a unit test which checks the result of our projection against the more expensive full S-Z integral for cell-by-cell. They agree to within 6 decimal places for the test cluster I set up.  

3) Added the current CMB temperature as a physical constant.   

4) Added a `requires_import` decorator to allow tests to silently pass if required modules aren't installed on the testing platform.   

5) Added a new answer test which compares a NumPy array to the previous result given a user-defined function that generates it.   

6) I set up a couple of answer tests, but I can't get them to run and generate results for some reason. What happens is that `can_run_pf` returns `False` because `AnswerTestingTest.result_storage == None`, but I don't know for sure why. If anyone else could take a look at this that would be appreciated. 

UPDATE: Includes GenericImageTest. All answer tests now pass.

UPDATE: Refactored the image comparison as per @ngoldbaum's suggestion. My tests still pass, also checked that the PlotWindow tests also pass. 

UPDATE: Catching errors
